column2: P5JS - Exploring Colors with Variables!
What you'll do
In the first part of this activity, you'll learn how to use variables to make P5JS even easier!
Hey, {{user_name}}! Today, I want to show you something cool I just learned!
Let's start up the online editor for p5.js - If it doesn't open automatically, click this link: https://editor.p5js.org/
Before we can dive in, we need to do a little setup work for our canvas. Let's add a square, and make it follow your mouse!

To make the square, make a blank line inside the curly braces ( {} ) for draw(), after the line that says background(220). On that new line, type: rect(mouseX, mouseY, 20, 20); Now, if you press the Play button, you'll see a white box following your mouse!

You might be wondering why the rectangle is following your mouse... It's because mouseX and mouseY are built-in names for the vertical (top-to-bottom) and horizontal (side-to-side) position of your mouse cursor! They're words that represent special information in p5.js. Let's use some more of them!
We'll use some more code to give the shape some color. Start a new line right above rect(..., and type fill('blue');. When you press the Play button, the square will be blue.

blue is like mouseX - it's a word that represents special information. In this case, it's a specifc color. What if we wanted to make our own color, though? We'll have to make a special name for it, and that's where variables come in!
Let's create our variable right at the beginning, above setup(), on line 1. Go to line 1 and type x = 'blue'. This tells the program that when you say x, you actually mean blue.

Now that we've created our new variable, let's use it. Go to the line that says fill('blue');, delete 'blue', and type x in its place. Before you press Play, what do you expect to happen? Check and see if you're right!
The square is still blue! Cool, huh? Variables can point to text, numbers, or even more complicated kinds of information! In this case, we have a variable pointing to some text - blue.
So far, so good. Let's keep using variables, and do some more cool things with them! Our square has a black outline, so let's use variables to change that.

To change the square's outline, we'll use stroke(). Make a new line above the line with fill(x);, and on that line, type stroke(x);. If stroke() controls the outline color, and we're giving it x, what do you expect to happen? Press Play and find out!
The square is now all blue, even the outermost part! Great work! For our next trick, let's make the stroke a different color. Any ideas on how to do that?
Let's do it with another variable! Make a new line underneath x = 'blue' and type y = 'orange'.
We also need to tell the stroke() to use the new variable - so change stroke(x); to stroke(y);, and press Play!
Now the outside of our square is orange! As you can see, variables can be super helpful. You can use them as many times as you like - imagine how much typing you could save!
If you're logged in to the p5.js online editor, now would be a great time to save your work - You don't want to lose everything you did if you accidentally close this tab.
Now that we have the basics of variables down, next time I'll show you how to create random colors using variables! See you then!
